The third volume is in some respects more interesting than either of the two previously published, and, from ample materials in the shape of correspondence, which must be within the reach of Mr. Lockhart's arm, it will form one of the most delightful biographies ever published—Edinburgh Observer.

The present volume of these charmingly written and most interesting Memoirs contains some of the brightest, as well as darkest passages in the life of Sir Walter Scott. Beginning with the “flitting” of the poet's family from Ashestiel to Abbotsford, with the characteristic details of so important an event, the literary progress and personal fortunes of Sir Walter are minutely related in the succeeding chapters; the publication of Rokeby, the Bridal of Triermain, the Lord of the Isles, and, greater than all, Waverley and Guy Mannering. The interior history of these popular works, particularly the novels, is full of the deepest interest, and nothing could be better calculated to satisfy the reader's curiosity than the thorough unfolding of the author's proceedings, which has been done in Mr. Lockhart's happiest manner. Five chapters of the present volume are occupied with the Diary kept by Sir Walter Scott during a voyage to the Shetland Isles. It is full of curious and characteristic matter, containing the poet's personal observations in the course of the voyage. It was intended for a circle of friends, but, nevertheless, it possesses every quality which could render such a record interesting to the public. Indeed the real man is nowhere more clearly unfolded than in the almost unpremediated memoranda of which the Diary is composed.—Edinburgh Evening Post.

div.head: G
div.p: Mr. Lockhart has amply redeemed the pledge which his first volume gave, and, so far from there being any falling off, either in the execution or interest of the narrative, there is a marked improvement at every step we take.—Glasgow Argus.

div.head: H
div.p: Another delightful volume. It brings the narrative down to the year 1815; and contains a little world of character, fact, and anecdote made yet more interesting by the good taste with which it is presented. A diary of a visit to Stromness, the Hebrides, and other places in the north, shows how completely the mind of Sir Walter Scott was able to invest an apparently barren subject with strong interest.—Hull Packet.

div.head: I
div.p: The interest of this biography continues undiminished; for no cloud has yet come over the brilliant career of Scott, and he is engaged in a thousand schemes, full of life, hope, business, imagination, or pleasure. Here we have him, in the short space of three years, (1812 to 1815), planting and improving at Abbotsford, (he has now become a laird, and discharges all his family and social duties with exemplary kindness and hospitality), but we find him first a Clerk of the Court of Session—publishing his poems of Rokeby and the Bridal of Triermain—refusing the Poet-Laureateship—writing letters to Byron, Joanna Baillie, Crabbe, and fifty others—publishing his edition of Swift—(a trifle of nineteen volumes)—writing Essays for the Encyclopedia—publishing Waverley—(having written the second and third volumes in three weeks!)—making a voyage to Shetland and Orkney—publishing the Lord of the Isles—writing in six weeks the novel of Guy Mannering—visiting Brussels, and writing Paul's Letters, and his poem of the Field of Waterloo, &c. &c. When was so much of mind, of inventive genius and observation, and of stirring life, crowded into three years of one man's existence? We were prepared by the comments of some periodical critics to find this volume not so good as the two first, but we can honestly say, that in the perusal we discovered no falling off. Mr. Lockhart certainly does not do much himself, but his materials are admirably disposed for effect, and they are so rich in themselves that they require no setting at the hands of another.—Inverness Courier.

div.head: K
div.p: This work, as it progresses, grows upon our affections. The literary associations with which it is conversant, and the ever-varying scintillations of a genius such as Scott's, must render the perusal of the valuable correspondence contained in it a matter both of delight and of instruction, and, we will not say to Scotsmen, but to Britons, of honest pride, that Sir Walter was one of us. Every Borderer should make himself master of a copy of this publication.—Kelso Chronicle.

div.head: L
div.p: This third volume of the Memoirs of Sir Walter Scott, comprises the important and critical period of his life, from 1812 to 1815, commencing with his removal from Ashestiel to Abbotsford, and including the publication of the first of the “Waverley Novels.” A large proportion of the volume is occupied with the embarrassments arising from the derangement of the affairs of Messrs. Ballantyne and Co., which began, it would appear, as early as 1812. Notwithstanding the anxiety naturally superinduced by this constantly depressing cause, we find Scott, instead of relaxing his literary labours, continuing them with redoubled zeal and energy, and producing a succession of works, both in prose and poetry, which proved the indomitable ardour of his mind, the Herculean strength of his frame, and the inexhaustible resources of his genius. One portion of the present volume has afforded us very great pleasure in the perusal. We allude to the interesting Diary of his voyage in the lighthouse yacht to Nova Zembla, “and the Lord knows where.” It is an exquisite specimen of what might have been expected from him in the character of a traveller. We need scarcely add, that it is our conviction that the present volume will be read with increasing interest. The work is destined to become a part of the standard literature of Great Britain, and, as such, will occupy a place in every library of consequence in the world.—Liverpool Standard.

This volume comprises about three years of the poet's life, viz. from 1812 to 1815, a period short as to time but rich in events, both with respect to the hero and the world in general, since it included the publication of Waverley and Guy Mannering, the escape of Buonaparte from Elba, and his final defeat at Waterloo. We mention these events in conjunction, because in some of the charming correspondence with which the biography is enriched, Scott expresses his opinions on passing political events with all the zeal and fervour of his nature. The volume contains Scott's diary of a trip to the Orkney and Shetland Isles, which abounds in touches of descriptive incident and character, just such as we should expect from such an observer on such a voyage. Lockhart's Life of Scott is likely to be, if it proceeds as it has begun, one of the best executed and most interesting pieces of biography in the language.—Liverpool Mercury.

div.head: M
div.p: The third volume continues this most entertaining Memoir from 1812 to 1815, and embraces an account of a highly interesting portion of Scott's life. The most interesting portion is Sir Walter's diary of a voyage to the Shetland and Orkney islands, which occupied the whole month of August and part of September 1814. “It affords,” says his biographer, “such a complete and artless portraiture of the man, as he was in himself, and as he mingled with his friends and companions, at one of the most interesting periods of his life, that I am persuaded every reader will be pleased to see it printed in its original state.” Besides this, the volume contains excellent letters to various correspondents, and an account of Sir Walter's excursion to the field of Waterloo, &c.—Manchester Courier.

div.head: N
div.p: This volume commences with Sir Walter's removal to Abbotsford, and proceeds to give an account of his correspondence with Crabbe, and the publication of Rokeby and the Bridal of Triermain. We have then narrated the troubles in which Sir Walter became involved by his connection with Ballantyne, further interesting correspondence, the insanity of Weber, with the very kind treatment of him by Scott; the publication of Swift and of Waverley. The poet then took a voyage to the Shetland Isles, the Orknies, and the neighbourhood, of which the author judiciously gives us the whole of Sir Walter's diary. As a part of his life, the idea was excellent to copy the whole into the present volume; and beyond this, it has all the interest and effect of a separate work. The diary occupies about five chapters, and is so replete with information, and so delightful with varied interest, that it is to us matter of astonishment it never came before the public in a corrected state till this time. The Field of Waterloo was next published, and then come Paul's Letters to his Kinsfolk. The volume ends with 1815, and contains, we should not forget, an appendix of the Durham Garland.—Newcastle Tyne Mercury.

div.head: P
div.p:
Among the interesting passages which crowd every
page of this volume, it is almost impossible to give a preference; the following refers to his introduction to the Prince Regent in 1815, and to a very current anecdote regarding his disclaimer of the authorship of the Novels..... This brings us to the close of the volume. The work increases in interest as it proceeds, and this portion of it is enriched by the insertion of a larger quantity of Scott's MSS, than either of its predecessors.—Perthshire Courier.

div.head: S
div.p: The interest excited by the perusal of the two preceding volumes of this work is still kept up, we may say increased, by the present. We congratulate Mr. Lockhart on the discrimination displayed by him in selecting materials for these volumes, and we would recommend all the admirers of the once Great Unknown to place this alongside his works on the shelves of their library. In these will be found, as it were, the main spring which guided the hand now withering in the dust, at whose beckon, knowledge opened her treasury, antiquity her locked-up stores, and formed them into shapes for the amusement, instruction, and admiration of the world.—Sheffield Iris.

div.head: A
div.p: The interest of this work increases so deeply as it proceeds, that the prospect of its termination excites pain and regret. We never remember to have read a biography which more strongly enchained the attention, or exhibited so distinct and vivid a picture of the original. Scott has, indeed, in his letters, unconsciously employed his inimitable skill in sketching characters upon himself; and we doubt very much, whether the most perfect master of biography could have brought out the character of Sir Walter Scott with half the force and strength of outline with which it is reflected from his own correspondence. The fourth volume introduces his biographer, Mr. Lockhart, as an actor on the scene, and his description of Scott is highly graphic.—Asiatic Journal.

The novelist's letters to his friends on these and other subjects, form one of the greatest charms of the work. Indeed, he seems to have been a most indefatigable letter-writer, so much so, that it is difficult to comprehend how he found any time at all to devote to authorship, even allowing, which appears to be the case, that he attended to his voluminous correspondence whilst sitting in the Court of Session, and supposed to be listening to the speeches of learned counsel at the Bar. Besides an account of the negotiations for bringing out certainly by far the best batch of his novels, the fourth volume contains many interesting incidents of his private history, among others the death of some of his near and dear friends, his own illness, a visit to London, and his elevation to a baronetcy. Such of our readers as can afford to purchase the work should hasten to do so. They will read it with some portion of that pleasure with which, in days of yore, they coned over the damp sheets of Ivanhoe or the Antiquary; and with every person of good taste it will appear a desideratum to have it placed on the same shelf with the never-dying works of the great man, the incidents of whose life and death it details.—Aberdeen Herald.

We have characterised this Volume as more interesting than its predecessors. The cause may be, that during the time to which it refers, the biographer became personally acquainted with “The Great Unknown,” and is therefore able to link together the correspondence it contains (which also is Scott's best) by a richer chain of anecdote and personal reminiscence, than he could command for the earlier portion of his work. We find plenteous notices, too, of the increasing splendour of Abbotsford, delightfully intermixed with glimpses of Scott's benevolence and consideration as a landlord and a master.—Athenoeum.

div.head: C
div.p: This volume comprises an interesting portion of Sir Walter's life from the year 1816 to 1820, when we find him in the full vigour of his genius, and though labouring under a painful disease, which attacked him occasionally for more than a twelvemonth, yet pouring forth with unabated prodigality, the treasures of his mind, and contributing, during this short space, a larger stock to the public amusement than other writers during a lifetime. The biography also derives additional interest from the circumstance, that it has now attained to that period where the writer describes from his own observations; and his sketch of Sir Walter, with his favourites of the brute creation gambolling around him, and of his manner of conversing, of his tastes, his habits, and the aspect of his study, is peculiarly lively and graphic. Nor less amusing, and equally just is his estimate of his conversational powers. The interest of the work is fully maintained in this volume, which contains much amusing detail, abundance of anecdote, and the most characteristic illustrations of the manners and mind of the great literary hero of modern times, related, too, in an easy, agreeable, and popular style.—Courant (Edinburgh.).

This volume, owing to many circumstances, is fully more entertaining on the whole than its immediate predecessor. It contains more of domestic and personal detail—next to those which relate to Scott's literary speculations, by far the most interesting portions of these memoirs. These details include some curious festive scenes, in which the Ballantynes, who have acquired altogether in the course of the narrative a sort of amusing importance, perform a distinguished part. All this portion of the volume is exceedingly entertaining.

Amongst the personal details of particular interest is an account of the attentions of the Prince Regent to Scott. His offer of the laureatship, which the poet declined, and subsequently successfully employed his interest to procure for Southey—his promotion to a baronetcy, and some notices of a severe illness with which Scott was attacked in 1817, and which subjected him from time to time, for a long while afterward's, to great bodily suffering. Such is a sketch of a few, a very few, of the most striking points in these two interesting volumes. They, of course, convey but an inadequate idea of their multifarious contents; but to give a fuller, would require a much greater space than we can afford. We must, therefore, refer the reader to the ample bill of fair, served up under the title of “contents,” or better still, to the work itself.

We cannot, however, dismiss these volumes without adverting for a moment to one or two general impressions which a perusal of them will not fail to make on the reader. He will be struck with the amazing amount of literary labour which Scott's unwearying industry was capable of accomplishing, with the extraordinary elasticity of mind which enabled him to seize on subject after subject with unpausing rapidity, and unabating energy, and with that still more wonderful facility of composition, which enabled him to accomplish in a few weeks what any other man would have thought cleverly done in as many months. Such an instance, in short, of rapidity of conception, with facility of execution, is wholly unparalleled in the history of literary exertion. The reader will not fail, also, to be struck with the singular and beautiful simplicity of character, the unpretending manners and benevolence of nature which is associated with these astonishing powers, nor to remark that there is not, throughout the whole of these two volumes, [3 and 4,] one single harsh or discordant note—one single circumstance to disturb the perfect harmony of fine moral associations.

Lastly, the reader will be struck with the fulness and frankness of the biographer's disclosures, and will acknowledge that they leave no reasonable curiosity ungratified. Mr. Lockhart has not had a very great deal to do in the case of these two volumes; but what he has had to do, he has done admirably.—Scotsman.

div.head: D
div.p: Each succeeding volume of these highly interesting Memoirs affords the clearest evidence of the single-heartedness of purpose possessed by this gifted being, the emanation of whose vivid fancy and enlightened mind will live and triumph as long as the fascinating charms of imagination hold theirs way over the human breast.

As far as he has proceeded, Mr. Lockhart has proved himself fully equal to the important work he has undertaken; and, jealously watchful as we might be of the absence of the most minute incident in the life of him whom from infancy we have loved, we could not select a single portion of the four published volumes with which we could disagree or cavil. They indeed

and whether describing Scott as the “lion” of the London “magnates,” or the contented centre of his own happy family circle—his books, his children, and what, as he did himself, we may class with his family, his noble dogs, they are equally felicitous. The letters which he has given us, written by the “Lion of the North,” and; his entire correspondence with the leading literary, scientific, and political characters of the day, are rife with interest of the most pleasing description; and we look for the appearance of the volume almost with as much anxiety as we did of yore for the appearance of a new triumph in romance, bearing on its title-page the thrilling announcement, “By the author of Waverley.”—Dublin Evening Packet.

Lockhart's personal reminiscences of Scott come into play in this volume, and give a fresh and vivid interest to the work, beyond anything to be found in the three preceding volumes. Such a sketcher as Peter Morris, with such subjects as Wilson, Blackwood, Constable, the Ballantynes, &c. cannot but be highly piquant. Another feature of great interest in this volume, lies in the letters written by Scott to his son after he joined his regiment, which form an admirable model of paternal counsel, conveyed with all the frank and easy confidence of one man writing to another as his bosom companion. The rest of the correspondence throughout this volume is also superior, upon the whole, we think, to what the three first volumes bear. If we add to all this that the literary history of the works produced by Scott, during the period which this volume embraces, possesses in many instances a new and profound interest, from the circumstance that some of the best of those works were dictated amidst the pains and groans of a subduing malady, we have still only imperfectly stated the attractions of a volume which we think is almost without a rival in the annals of our literature.—Dumfries Herald.

div.head: E
div.p: What is there in literature that more interests us than that department which treats of the actions and fortunes of individuals? In truth, the incidents of the life of an eminent man, is not unfrequently the history of his times and nation; and if ever this were true of any individual, it undoubtedly is so of Scott. If, too, the great end of biography is to make us acquainted with the nature of man, what can better conduce to it than faithful portraits? This then admitted, and we think it will scarcely be contested, we have in the work before us a grouping of characters, such as in the most effectual way enables us to make progress in this branch of knowledge. The opening volume, of which we have before spoken, was ample, its successors have all the marks of authenticity, and abound alike with anecdote and incident. A manly character runs through the whole, and there is something delightful in the perusal.—Exeter Flying Post.

The fourth volume of this work, is, we think, of more general interest than the preceding ones. Its contents embrace Scott's correspondence, referring to the chief events of his life from the years 1816 to 1820, and are plesingly interspersed with Mr. Lockhant's own remimiscences of him, and many of his contemporaries. The chief attraction of the present volume appears to be, that it places the character of the man in its proper colours before the reader. We have him divested of all reserve or ceremony, such as he appeared in the bosom of his family, and it may be readily supposed, that as his biographer proceeds further with his personal recollection of the bard, who was destined afterwards to be his father-in-law, he will bring additional spirit to his undertaking.—Excter Western Luminary.

div.head: I
div.p: The value of this volume, like that of its predecessors, consists chiefly in the richness of its gathered materials,—it is Scott that speaketh. Mr. Lockhart, however, has added some personal reminiscences and anecdotes, worthy of preservation, with some interesting details of the poet's habits—his great Sunday dinners and drives—his love of hearty breakfasts, and old-fashioned dishes at dinner, &c. There is a very humourous description of the dinners usually given by James Ballantyne on the appearance of a new novel of the Waverley series. The demeanour of Scott, the meek solemnity of Ballantyne, and the toasting of the Great Unknown, &c., are all admirably let off. We admire also the frankness with which he has dealt with his subject. There is apparently no suppression for the sake of saving his hero—no fastidious dryness in burrying into light all his private tastes, opinions, and transactions. In this manner the book will form a counterpart to Boswell's inimitable biography, both as regards the chief actor in the scene, and all his illustrious contemporaries.—Inverness Courier.

div.head: L
div.p: The fourth volume of this delightful biography shows Sir Walter Scott in the height of his fame and fortune, publishing with wonderful rapidity the tales which fascinated the world, and at the same time carrying on a correspondence so extensive, a friendly and literary intercourse so wide, and improvements in his estate at Abbotsford so various, that these alone would have filled up the whole time of any man of ordinary industry. This volume still increases the impression produced by the former of Scott's exceeding amiableness of character, and of his almost boundless versatility. At this period of his life he was attacked by a most painful and formidable complaint, cramp in the stomach, which disabled him from writing his novels with his own hand, as in former and subsequent periods; but in the midst of agonies of pain he often dictated with indomitable energy; and the following is one of the most remarkable instances in the history of literature, of the triumph of imagination and genius over the extreme of bodily anguish.—Leeds Mercury.

Our interest is increased as we proceed with the perusal of these admirable memoirs. The present volume unfolds to us a very important portion of the history of the illustrious Scott, including the period from 1816 to 1820, during which time his different publications appeared in very rapid succession, and contributed to increase his popularity, as well as to stimulate the curiosity of the public as to the identity of the mysterious author. It gives a minute account of the publication of “Paul's Letters to his Kinsfolk”—“Guy Mannering”—“The Antiquary”—“Tales of My Landlord”—“Harold the Dauntless”—“Rob Roy”—“The Heart of Mid-Lothian”—“The Bride of Lammermoor”—“Ivanhoe”—The Visionary”—and “The Monastery,” together with a great number of smaller works. The letters here published are very numerous, and possessed of great attractions. Extensive as Scott's correspondence was, it is not a matter of surprise that this department of the Memoirs should be one of the most edifying and amusing. The anecdotes related are as varied and characteristic as those dispersed through the preceding volumes. We shall endeavour to make room for several extracts in our succeeding numbers. In the meantime we can do no better than recommend our readers to purchase the volume for themselves.—Liverpool Standard.

div.head: M
div.p: This is the most interesting volume that has yet been published of these admirable Memoirs. The correspondence of Scott in this volume is highly interesting, and for the most part entertaining; and the same may be said of the anecdotes of his domestic life, and of his intercourse with society, with which the volume abounds. Amongst the most striking events recorded in this part of the work, are the visits of Washington Irving, Lady Byron, and Sir David Wilkie, to Abbotsford—the former of whom has given a spirited sketch of his visit, strikingly illustrative of the poet's habits and tastes. The account of his Den in Edinburgh, and of his mode of spending his time in Modern Athens, forms a highly entertaining chapter of the work: indeed every page of the volume will repay perusal.—Manchester Courier.

div.head: P
div.p: The fourth volume of this most fascinating of works and lives, takes up the narrative at the publication of Paul's Letters in 1816, and concludes shortly after the period of his elevation to the Baronetcy in 1820. The interval includes but a short space of time, but a mass of literary labour, besides his usual abundant contributions to the periodical literature of the day, with the addition of his extensive private correspondence, of which the present volume almost entirely consists. The latter is more of a domestic character than hitherto, to which his severe illness in 1819, and the departure of his eldest son “from the nest—to wing his own way against the storm,” mainly contributed. But in whatever view the correspondence runs, its character is equally fascinating and equally beyond criticism.—Perthshire Courier.

div.head: S
div.p: In this volume Mr. Lockhart appears upon the scene speaking of matters within his own knowledge; painting domestic details, of course with greater freshness, and describing collateral things, such as the various society of Edinburgh in which Scott mixed, with a portrait-like reality. His picture of the brothers BALLANTYNE, and of the party given by JAMES when a new Waverley novel was on the tapis, is richly ludicrous.—The Spectator.
